logitr 1.2

    • Estimating mixed logit models

    Estimating mixed logit models

    mxl_models.Rmd

    First, load the logitr library:

    library('logitr')
    ## Loading required package: nloptr

    We’ll use the Yogurt data set from the mlogit package

    head(yogurt)
    ##   id obsID alt choice price feat   brand dannon hiland weight yoplait
## 1  1     1   1      0   8.1    0  dannon      1      0      0       0
## 2  1     1   2      0   6.1    0  hiland      0      1      0       0
## 3  1     1   3      1   7.9    0  weight      0      0      1       0
## 4  1     1   4      0  10.8    0 yoplait      0      0      0       1
## 5  1     2   1      1   9.8    0  dannon      1      0      0       0
## 6  1     2   2      0   6.4    0  hiland      0      1      0       0

    Mixed logit models in the preference space

    To estimate the model, use the logitr() function. In the example below, the randPars argument is used to denote which parameters will be modeled with a distribution. In this example, only the 'feat' attribute is modeled as normally distributed, so all other parameters will be modeled with fixed coefficients. Since this model is non-convex, it is recommended that you use a multi-start approach to search for different local minima (in this example, I set numMultiStarts = 1 for brevity).

    mxl_pref <- logitr(
  data       = yogurt,
  choiceName = 'choice',
  obsIDName  = 'obsID',
  parNames   = c('price', 'feat', 'dannon', 'hiland', 'yoplait'),
  randPars   = c(feat = 'n'),
  options    = list(
    numMultiStarts = 1,
    numDraws       = 500))
    Running Model
Done!

    You can view a summary of the model output with the summary() function:

    summary(mxl_pref)
    ## =================================================
## MODEL SUMMARY: 
##                          
## Model Space:   Preference
## Model Run:         1 of 1
## Iterations:            36
## Elapsed Time:   0h:2m:25s
## Weights Used?:      FALSE
## 
## Model Coefficients: 
##             Estimate StdError    tStat   pVal signif
## price      -0.392768 0.026708 -14.7061 0.0000    ***
## feat.mu     0.351933 0.204608   1.7200 0.0856      .
## dannon      0.663863 0.055794  11.8984 0.0000    ***
## hiland     -3.324270 0.164101 -20.2575 0.0000    ***
## yoplait     1.458054 0.095512  15.2656 0.0000    ***
## feat.sigma  2.360350 0.515567   4.5782 0.0000    ***
## ---
## Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
## 
## Model Fit Values: 
##                                      
## Log.Likelihood.         -2645.9202707
## Null.Log.Likelihood.    -3343.7419990
## AIC.                     5303.8405000
## BIC.                     5338.5698000
## McFadden.R2.                0.2086948
## Adj..McFadden.R2            0.2069005
## Number.of.Observations.  2412.0000000
## 
## Summary of 10k Draws for Random Coefficients: 
##        Min.   1st Qu.    Median      Mean  3rd Qu.     Max.
## 1 -8.822073 -1.240571 0.3511815 0.3499323 1.942267 8.875534

    Since this model is a “preference” space model, you can use the result to compute the implied willingness to pay with the wtp() function:

    wtp_mxl_pref = wtp(mxl_pref, priceName = 'price')
wtp_mxl_pref
    ##             Estimate StdError    tStat   pVal signif
## lambda      0.392768 0.026774  14.6700 0.0000    ***
## feat.mu     0.896034 0.538969   1.6625 0.0965      .
## dannon      1.690218 0.194729   8.6798 0.0000    ***
## hiland     -8.463706 0.525177 -16.1159 0.0000    ***
## yoplait     3.712257 0.478469   7.7586 0.0000    ***
## feat.sigma  6.009534 1.437360   4.1810 0.0000    ***

    Mixed logit models in the WTP space

    To estimate a mixed logit model in the WTP space, you have to add the modelSpace = "wtp" argument. You also must provide the priceName argument, which specified the name of the column in the data argument that is price. In this example, I model price with a fixed coefficient, but you could model it as a random parameter by specifying the randPrice argument (typically set to 'ln' for log-normal).

    Note also that I am using the computed WTP from the preference space model as the starting parameters. These values will only be used as the starting guess for the first iteration of a multi-start run.

    mxl_wtp = logitr(
  data       = yogurt,
  choiceName = 'choice',
  obsIDName  = 'obsID',
  parNames   = c('feat', 'dannon', 'hiland', 'yoplait'),
  priceName  = 'price',
  randPars   = c(feat = 'n'),
  # randPrice  = 'ln',
  modelSpace = 'wtp',
  options = list(
    numMultiStarts = 1,
    startVals      = wtp_mxl_pref$Estimate,
    startParBounds = c(-5, 5),
    numDraws       = 500))
    Running Model
Done!

    You can view a summary of the model output with the summary() function:

    summary(mxl_wtp)
    ## =================================================
## MODEL SUMMARY: 
##                                  
## Model Space:   Willingness-to-Pay
## Model Run:                 1 of 1
## Iterations:                   112
## Elapsed Time:           0h:8m:53s
## Weights Used?:              FALSE
## 
## Model Coefficients: 
##             Estimate StdError    tStat   pVal signif
## lambda      0.392768 0.026708  14.7062 0.0000    ***
## feat.mu     0.896032 0.534239   1.6772 0.0936      .
## dannon      1.690215 0.172674   9.7885 0.0000    ***
## hiland     -8.463701 0.517775 -16.3463 0.0000    ***
## yoplait     3.712255 0.161357  23.0065 0.0000    ***
## feat.sigma  6.009556 1.323045   4.5422 0.0000    ***
## ---
## Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
## 
## Model Fit Values: 
##                                      
## Log.Likelihood.         -2645.9202707
## Null.Log.Likelihood.    -3343.7419990
## AIC.                     5303.8405000
## BIC.                     5338.5698000
## McFadden.R2.                0.2086948
## Adj..McFadden.R2            0.2069005
## Number.of.Observations.  2412.0000000
## 
## Summary of 10k Draws for Random Coefficients: 
##        Min.   1st Qu.    Median      Mean  3rd Qu.    Max.
## 1 -22.46139 -3.158553 0.8941192 0.8909386 4.945094 22.5975

    If you want to compare the WTP from the two different model spaces, use the wtpCompare() function:

    wtp_mxl_comparison <- wtpCompare(mxl_pref, mxl_wtp, priceName = 'price')
    wtp_mxl_comparison
    ##                    pref           wtp difference
## lambda         0.392768     0.3927684  3.900e-07
## feat.mu        0.896034     0.8960325 -1.530e-06
## dannon         1.690218     1.6902148 -3.210e-06
## hiland        -8.463706    -8.4637009  5.070e-06
## yoplait        3.712257     3.7122551 -1.900e-06
## feat.sigma     6.009534     6.0095564  2.241e-05
## logLik     -2645.920271 -2645.9202707  0.000e+00

    Note that the WTP will not be the same between preference space and WTP space MXL models. This is because the distributional assumptions in MXL models imply different distributions on WTP depending on the model space. See Train and Weeks (2005) and Sonnier, Ainslie, and Otter (2007) for details on this topic:

    • Train K, Weeks M (2005). “Discrete Choice Models in Preference Space and Willingness- to-Pay Space.” In R Scarpa, A Alberini (eds.), Applications of Simulation Methods in Environmental and Resource Economics, volume 6 of The Economics of Non-Market Goods and Resources, pp. 1-16. Springer-Verlag.
    • Sonnier G, Ainslie A, Otter T (2007). “Heterogeneity Distributions of Willingness-to-Pay in Choice Models.” Quantitative Marketing and Economics, 5(3), 313–331.
